name: Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta
description: Minimally invasive resuscitative technique using an endovascular balloon catheter to occlude the aorta, providing hemorrhage control and hemodynamic support in trauma or non-compressible torso hemorrhage. Serves as a bridge to definitive surgical repair.

mechanism.principle: Aortic occlusion increases proximal blood pressure while reducing distal hemorrhage

hemodynamic_effect.proximal: Increased SBP, improved coronary and cerebral perfusion
hemodynamic_effect.distal: Reduced blood flow to hemorrhage site

mechanism.analogy: Less invasive alternative to resuscitative thoracotomy with aortic cross-clamp

zone_1.location: Left subclavian artery to celiac artery

zone_2.location: Celiac artery to lowest renal artery
zone_2.note: AVOID - occlusion causes visceral ischemia without benefit

zone_3.location: Lowest renal artery to aortic bifurcation

insertion.length: Estimated by external landmarks or fluoroscopy

inflation.confirm: Position with imaging if available (XR, fluoro)
inflation.inflate: Until loss of distal pulse or resistance

technique.partial_reboa: Partial occlusion to minimize ischemia time

ischemia_reperfusion.limit: Zone 1: 60-90 min max; Zone 3: longer tolerated

outcomes.survival_benefit: Improved in selected patients vs resuscitative thoracotomy

clinical_pearls: Zone 1 = above viscera (abdominal hemorrhage); Zone 3 = below kidneys (pelvic)
NEVER inflate in Zone 2 - causes visceral ischemia without benefit
REBOA is a BRIDGE to definitive care, not definitive treatment
Ischemia time is critical - minimize occlusion duration, consider partial REBOA
learning_objectives: Describe the aortic zones and appropriate zone selection for REBOA
Explain the hemodynamic effects of aortic balloon occlusion
Identify complications and time limitations of REBOA

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
